through and the the it is the uh the guidelines themselves specify a process
that is in that same vein uh voluntary and collaborative in dealing with the security vulnerabilities to go forward

right if one party is trying to take advantage of the other uh in in resolve in getting doing something with the

going and we like to point out that this is but one model there are many ways that one can go about dealing with uh
security vulnerabilities uh and in both the discovery and uh responding process
uh but this is one that we think is probably one going to be the most effective based on the collective experience of the organization so the
process itself can be broken down into a variety of phases Discovery notification
investigation resolution and release each of these have parts that go
on with it obviously it begins with the finder identifying the suspected vulnerability contacting the vendor to
notify that there is an issue going on here that something needs to happen the vendor works with the finder to develop
the to investigate the report and find out what's going on the parties agree on what the response is going to be because
there are several possibilities for how one might uh reply to a vulnerability
and at the end there is release right which is important to note U it's uh definitely something that I think

a variety of reasons so drilling into these in a little bit more detail for you okay um
the guidelines assume that the uh that the the research comes up along the way that there's that any however it happens
the security vulnerability is discovered Can Happen by intentional investigation it can happen accidentally it can happen
through the normal use of the software doesn't particularly matter but it is in cumbent on the finder of the

somebody's already found for example and perhaps is already fixed uh whether it is in uh the latest patching uh the
current versions of the software that's out um and preferably that there is a means for reproducing the problem uh
makes it a lot easier for everybody if they're if you're able to do that during the notification process
it's incumbent upon the vendor to provide a predictable point of contact something that is easy for people to
discover so that we don't have situations like there have been many times in the past when uh the V the
finder is not able to decide how to how to notify the vendor or they send it off to someplace and it never goes anywhere

of those things uh the vendor sorry the finder sends a vulnerability summary that has some information the vendor
acknowledges that they received that they don't just take it in and and uh ignore that don't deal with the uh with
the finder on any basis and the parties negotiate to find an appropriate type of Engagement for the process for uh
developing through going through to release during the investigation most of
this is done on the part of the vendor uh the vendor may go back to the finder from time to time to ask for

publish their findings if they uh even if they agree with the uh with the vendor's conclusion but we've talked

whether this goes into a maintenance release a a service pack uh the uh
configuration change that may be appropriate to do or if the a patch needs to be released U some time frame

uh to make sure that they are sharing information the vendor and the finder are sharing information uh about how the

things that the guidelines uh call for is for the documentation of the fixes
regardless of where it goes in U I'm sure we're all aware that there have been in the past many instances where

proposed that you should not do that that if you have a security fix in the in your software you should document

that go about into the vulnerability report uh what the affected software is the risk that it poses what the users
need to do and any known side effects of the fix which as we all know going to be a significant issue as well
we also call for a grace period after the availability of the fix of 30 days
during which what we refer to as supplementary data is not released that supplementary data is things that are
essentially going to help the bad guys more than the good guys if we can use those terms in which the the idea here
is to essentially hold back on the technical detail of how you go about exploiting it whether that's exploit
code that actually demonstrates or the specific step-by-step processes that one would go through

much open to interpretation on the part of the parties that are involved okay so
